answers: "How Much Land Does a Man Need?" [or "How Much Land Does a Man Require?"; or "Mnogo li cheloveku zemli nuzhno?"]
The Death of Ivan Ilych [or Smert' Ivana Ilyicha] <Jose>
parts: Name this author, who wrote about the title character's fall from a snowy roof in his story "Alyosha the Pot." He also penned War and Peace.

Tolstoy's other short works includes this story, in which Pahom collapses while trying to acquire property from the Bashkirs. Ironically, "six feet of Earth" is the answer to this story's title question.
Tolstoy also wrote this novella about a judge served by Gerasim; the judge dies soon after he falls while hanging some curtains.

answers: Juana the Mad [or Joanna the Mad; or Juana I; or Joanna I; or Juana la Loca]
parts: Name this queen of Castille who refused to bury the dead body of her husband Philip the Handsome. This mother of Charles V spent most of her adult life confined to a castle in Tordesillas.
Juana was the second daughter of this queen of Castile. Her marriage to Ferdinand of Aragon united the Spanish nation.

Another one of Isabella's daughters, Maria, married into this Portuguese royal dynasty whose members included Henry the Navigator. Portugal's later ruling house, the Braganza, began as a cadet branch of this dynasty.
Name this Greek goddess of youth, known in Rome as Juventus. Her roles included helping Hera enter her chariot.
Hebe's primary role was as cupbearer to the gods, a position she held until she married Heracles. She was replaced in the role by this beautiful Trojan prince, who had been abducted by Zeus.
Hebe was also responsible for drawing the baths for this Greek god of war.
Name this impresario, who founded and managed a group of "Follies" that made lavish theatrical productions in the early 20th century.
The Ziegfeld Follies mostly performed in the district of New York City named for this group of theatres, whose name has become synonymous with the musicals it puts out.
"Shine On, Harvest Moon" was a song put out by this group of music publishers in the early 20th century America. It is named for a specific location in between two avenues in New York City.

The Phillips Curve depicts the trade-off between inflation and this other quantity. Shifts in an economy are responsible for the "structural" form of this phenomenon, which is defined as the percentage of the work force actively seeking work.
This economist argued that the Phillips Curve is vertical in the long-run as part of his theory of the natural rate of unemployment. He is also credited with devising the Golden Rule savings rate.
During the 1970s, Milton Friedman criticized the Phillips Curve because the U.S. experienced this phenomenon, in which inflation rates and unemployment both rise. Its name was coined by Iain Macleod.
Name this poetic "king of kings" whose plinth instructs "Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!"
"Ozymandias" is a poem by this Romantic author of "Ode to the West Wind".

Horace Smith's version of "Ozymandias," written in competition with Shelley's, imagines a future day on which a hunter will chase a wolf "thro' the wilderness where [this city] stood." A poem titled for this city begins "I wander thro' each charter'd street."

answers: Mars and Jupiter [accept in either order]
parts: Name this empirical "law" named for two astronomers, that roughly predicts the spacing of planets in the Solar System.

The mathematical formulation of the Titius-Bode law lead Johann Bode to predict the existence of a planet between these two other planets. As it turns out, an asteroid belt exists between this gas giant and this red planet.

The Titius-Bode law states that this value for a planet's orbit is equal to "4 plus n" where n is 3, 6, 12, 24, 48, and so on. Kepler's third law states that the square of a planet's period is equal to the cube of this quantity.

answers: Rhodesia [do not accept or prompt on "Zimbabwe"]
parts: Name this African country where the FRELIMO and RENAMO parties fought a protracted civil war.
RENAMO was originally sponsored as an anti-Communist organization by Ian Smith's white-dominated government in this country, which ceased to exist in 1979.

In 1975, Mozambique gained independence from this European country, which gave up its last colony of Macau in 1999. This country got its start on colonialism when Vasco de Gama sailed to India and began the conquest of Goa.
Name these transformations whose factor is represented by a gamma and which are used in special relativity theory.
Lorentz transformations are used to calculate time dilation and the contraction of this quantity.
A common representation of the Lorentz group uses the "bi" form of these mathematical entities, which transform to their negatives when the space is rotated 360 degrees.
Name this fringe theory that suggested one could sail over the edges of the world.

This author's fictional biography of Christopher Columbus popularized the misconception that the scholars of the medieval era believed in a flat earth. His book Salmagundi was the first to call New York City "Gotham."
Modern proponents of a flat earth theory allegedly include Ustaz Mohammed Yusuf, who founded this group known for its violent actions in the city of Chibok.
Name this trail that ended in Abilene and was used to drive cattle north to the railways.
Abilene is a city in this state. In 1859, the Wyandotte Constitution decided that this state would enter the Union as a free state, reversing this state's earlier pro-slavery Lecompton Constitution.

The southern terminus of the Chisholm Trail was in this state, whose longhorn cattle were also driven along the Goodnight-Loving Trail. The siege of the Alamo also occurred in what would become this state.

answers: Amitabha Buddha [or Amida Buddha or Amitayus Buddha]
parts: Name this buddha, who rules over the Western Paradise. According to a certain branch of Buddhism, chanting this man's name repeatedly allows one to enter the Western Paradise.
Many Pure Land Buddhists believe that the Western Paradise is a stepping-stone to this release from samsara.
Conventionally, one can attain nirvana by accumulating a positive kind of this concept, which is gained by good or bad deeds. This Sanskrit word literally means "work."
Name this type of desert area that features lush vegetation growing next to a water source.

Some oasis towns get their water using this technology, an underground channel developed by the Persian people thousands of years ago. The water supply of the Kharga Oasis was brought into town using this technology.
The Siwa Oasis in Egypt lends its name to one of the languages spoken by this ethnic group. Many members of this group prefer the term Amazigh to their common historical name.

answers: the Virgin Mary [or the Virgin; or Madonna; or Miriam]
parts: Identify this city which commissioned Ambrogio Lorenzetti to paint the Allegory of Good and Bad Government. Artists such as Simone Martini and Duccio also worked in this city.

The city of Siena commissioned a Maesta by Duccio, which depicts this person seated on a throne. Artists such as Simone Martini portrayed this person reading as an angel approaches in a common religious scene.

A later Sienese artist, Domenico Becafumi, worked in this style, which Giovanni Bellori characterized as coming from an artist's imagination rather than nature. This style is characterized by elongated figures and contrived poses.

answers: suite [or French Suite; or English Suite; or orchestral suite; or partita; or ordre; or ouverture]
parts: Name these collections of dances, which in their simplest form include an allemande, a courante, a sarabande, and a gigue.
Each of J.S. Bach's English Suites begins with one of these introductory pieces that were paired with fugues in The Well-Tempered Clavier.
The second movement of Bach's Orchestral Suite No. 3 is best known from this August Wilhelmj arrangement for violin and piano to be performed in the title manner.

answers: index fossils [accept guide fossils or indicator fossils or zone fossils]
parts: Name these archaeological objects studied by paleontologists.

This type of fossil is useful for dating since it is limited to a narrow geological period of time even though it is geographically widespread. It is often used to correlate layers of rock in different regions.
This kind of trace fossil is the petrified remains of dung. Like urolite fossils, this kind of fossil is useful in analyzing the diet of extinct species, such as dinosaurs.

answers: diabetes [or diabetes mellitus; or type I diabetes; or type II diabetes; do not accept "diabetes insipidus"]
parts: Name these compounds like aceto-acetate and beta-hydroxy-butyrate which are produced by the liver during fasting or starvation.

Patients with this disease accumulate ketone bodies and suffer from ketoacidosis, which also explains why sufferers of this disease often have breath that smells like acetone. This disease is treated with drugs like glargine and lispro.
The brain requires ketone bodies for synthesis of long-chain fatty acids, since those lipids cannot pass this barrier. This structure prevents large molecules from getting into the brain.

answers: World War II [or the Second World War]
parts: Identify this poet known by initials who wrote "Oread." She wrote about "Helena, hated of all Greece" in her epic poem Helen in Egypt.

Each part of H.D.'s The Walls Do Not Fall contains a date that references this conflict. The speaker sits "in one of the dives on Fifty-second Street" in W. H. Auden's poem about the start of this conflict, "September 1, 1939".
H. D. was a member of this group of poets. This movement included poets such as Amy Lowell and Ezra Pound and focused on "clarity of expression" through the use of precise visuals.
In return for tilling their lands and doing other work, peasants would be protected by the lord's armies as part of this system, whose name comes from the Germanic word for "property."
Rulers would give this piece of land to a lord, which the peasants would till. An urbarium was a register listing those who owned this kind of land.

This was the name given to a member of the social class that was not a serf. Ranked just below the gentry, this class was not rich but was able to own free land. Its name comes from a Latin word meaning "territory held without dues."

answers: a country [or a nation; accept "Let my country awake"]
parts: Identify this collection of poetry whose first poem opens with the declaration "Thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure."
In Gitanjali, the speaker exhorts God to let one of these entities awake "where the mind is without fear." One of these entities uses Tagore's hymn "Jana Gana Mana" for formal purposes.

Rabindranath Tagore's hymn "Jana Gana Mana" is written in a heavily Sanskritized register of Bengali and is the national anthem of this country, where Sanskrit and Bengali are two of the 22 official languages.
Name this genre of epic prose narratives from medieval Iceland, examples of which include the Laxdaela, and ones about Njal and Egil.

This author used the style of sagas as a model for her first novel, Gunnar's Daughter. This author wrote The Master of Hestviken tetralogy and created a character who wears a wreath at her wedding despite her seduction by Erlend.
The Laxdaela Saga and Njal's Saga are both set during Iceland's transition from paganism to this other religion.
